_header: O ye folks that been hard-hearted as a stone
Note: For MSS that lack the Prologue of five stanzas see 4105.
_description: John Lydgate ‘Dance of Macabre’ — eighty-four 8-line stanzas and envoy

BodSelSup53.First Lines:
O ȝee folkes harde hertid as a stoneWich to þe worlde
                    haue al ȝour aduertence…
BodSelSup53.Last Lines:
…Of her tunge I haue no suffisaunceHer corious metris in
                    englisshe to translate
BodSelSup53.Attributed Title: Here endith the daunce of deeth (at the end)
BodSelSup53.Editions:
Hammond,  Eleanor Prescott. 
             English Verse between Chaucer and Surrey.
         Durham, NC: Duke UP, 1927: 131-42.
Gray,  Douglas. 
             The Oxford Book of Late Medieval Verse and Prose.
         Oxford: Clarendon, 1985: 69-70.

CamTCC601.First Lines:
yE folkes harde hertyd as a stoneWhyche to the world haue your
                    aduertenceLyke as hit shuld last euer in oneWhere ys your wytte where
                    ys your prouydence…
CamTCC601.Last Lines:
…Of oþer tong I haue no suffysaunceHolde me excusyd my
                    name ys Iohn Lydgate
CamTCC601.Attributed Author:
dan Iohn Lydgate Monke of Bury (f. 278vb); lidgate Of Bury
                    (added b y two later hands, f. 284rb)
CamTCC601.Attributed Title:
hEre foloweth the Prologe of the Daunce of Machabre translatyd by dan Iohn
                    Lydgate Monke of Bury out of ffrensshe in to englyssh whyche now ys callyd the
                    Daunce of Poulys (f. 278vb); This daunce of machabre is depeyntyd
                    rychly at sent innocentes closter in parys in fraunce…payntyd in þe
                    cloystur at þe dispensys & request of Jankyn karpynter (f. added by
                    sixteenth-century hand, f. 278vb)

BLHar116.First Lines:
O ye folkes that bene harde harted as a stoneWhich to this world
                    yeue all your aduertans…
BLHar116.Last Lines:
…Of þer tonge I haue no suffisanceTheyere coryous metres
                    in ynglyche to translate
BLHar116.Note:
The last word in line 2, ‘aduertans’, was originally written
                    ?‘aduersitas’ and the scribe has traced darker letters to
                    convert.
BLHar116.Attributed Title:
The Davnce of Macabre (f. 129, by original scribe in rubric in upper
                    margin); Explicit vt super (f. 140v)
